Caption: Figure 1: An example DataSplash visualization with por- tals.
Figure 2: A visualization showing a satellite image in the parent canvas and a street map in a coordinated view tool.

Figure 3: Two snapshots of a map visualization having a movable magnifying glass with the lens and lens −1 de- pendencies enabled. The user can go from the before im- age (left) to the after image (right) either by repositioning the magnifying glass or by panning the magnified image inside the magnifying glass.
Figure 5: Summary of which user operations edit which frames.

Figure 6: A graph of the behavior having all the frame dependencies enabled. The nodes are displayed in order of conceptual distance from the user, from left to right. The name of each dependency is shown next to its corre- sponding edge.
Figure 7: A behavior with bypassing as the user pans upward in the parent canvas.

Figure 9: Two sequences of snapshots of a visualiza- tion having a coordinated view with the sticky, s-nav, s- nav−1 , and lens−1 dependencies enabled. The top two snapshots illustrate the display before and after reposi- tioning the coordinated view portal. The bottom two snapshots illustrate the display before and after panning left in either the parent or the child canvas.
Figure 8: A graph of DataSplash Behavior 3, which has all reverse dependencies derivable.

Figure 10: Two sequences of snapshots of a visualization having a portal with only the lens −1 dependencies en- abled, which is not forward derivable. The top two snap- shots illustrate the display before and after repositioning the coordinated view portal. The bottom two snapshots illustrate the display before and after panning the child canvas to the right.
Figure 11: A graph of DataSplash Behavior 6, which vi- olates dependency transitivity.
